author: REBECCA SULLIVAN AND AP
title: The dad bod is real: Men gain weight after having kids study says |
text:
REMEMBER all the fuss over the Dad Bod?
Made famous by Jon Hamm, Jason Segel and Leonardo DiCaprio, the term was coined by a 19-year-old American university student, Mackenzie Pearson, to describe the soft but moderately sculpted body found on many middle aged men.
It’s the kind of guy who might have played first grade rugby in high school, but work and children means he now runs just a few times a week, in between pizza and beer sessions.
And now, a new study has confirmed that the Dad Bod isn’t just a fantasy living in our heads, it’s a thing.
Many men gain a new sense of responsibility and purpose when they become fathers, but a US study suggests they also gain up to 2.3kg.
Dr. Craig Garfield of Northwestern University, the lead author of the study published on Tuesday by the American Journal of Men’s Health, said he could only speculate about what’s behind the extra weight.
“For men who become fathers, their whole life changes,” Garfield said. They may sleep less, exercise less, and experience more stress — all of which can lead to weight gain, he said.
Jon Hamm rocking the dad bod. Source: Supplied
It doesn’t help that the food selection at home may gradually change to include more things like “making chocolate chip cookies with the kids,” said Garfield.
For their work, the researchers looked at results from another study, which tracked the health of adolescents over two decades.
The researchers focused on teen boys and young men, comparing weight changes in the 3,400 who became dads and the 6,800 who didn’t. There was a difference.
After becoming a first-time dad, a typical 180cm man who lives with his child will gain an average of about 2kg, the study suggested. A same-sized man who does not live with his child can expect to gain nearly 1.6kg.
But a 180cm man who does not have children typically loses about 700 grams over the same time period, researchers found.
The study found men who lived with their children were a little heavier to begin with, on average, and ended up heavier than the absent fathers and the men who didn’t have kids.
According 2011-12 figures from the ABS , 70 per cent of Australian males are overweight or obese, compared to 56 per cent of women. Fat or Fit 23:37 Play video
With increased rates of obesity, come increased rates of heart disease, diabetes, and other health issues.
